prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 4150
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will make a 2-D map of the first velocity moment of the CO emission in Band 3 for NGC 4150 in order to make a rotation curve for the galaxy. The NGC 4150 has a diameter of about 2 arcminutes and will be mosaiced.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The observations require a spatial resolution of 2 arcsec which provides a linear resolution of about 150 pc at the typical target distance of 15 Mpc. This is the resolution necessary to resolve a core the size of 300 pc. A 2 arcsec beam also matches the resolution of the Palomar IFU allowing for a good complementarity between observations made with the two instruments. A velocity resolution of 2 km/s is needed to provide the velocity precision in the inner parts of the galaxies where the rotational velocities are less than 10 km/s. We desire a sensitivity to be able to detect at least one Milky Way-type GMC in each synthesized beam at a level of two sigma, though the peak of the emission is expected to be many sigma.
A Milky Way GMC has a typical diameter of about 50 pc. A GMC therefore subtends about 12% of a synthesized beam area at 15 Mpc. A typical GMC has a mean brightness temperature of about 4 K, so a single GMC will have an observed brightness temperature of 0.12 x 4K = 480 mK or 21 mJy/beam. For a 2 arcsec beam, and a 2 km/s velocity resolution, the Control and Performance tab reaches an rms sensitivity of 6.6 mJy/beam in 27 minutes. This is enough to detect a 2 km/s plane in a GMC at 3 sigma. Since a typical GMC has a linewidth of 8 km/s, a single GMC in the beam will be detected at 6 sigma.
Our primary interest is the CO line in band 1; the other 3 bands are set up in continuum mode. We expect the total width of the emission to be 100 - 200 km/s.`

The observations require a spatial resolution of 2 arcsec which provides a linear resolution of about 150 pc at the typical target distance of 15 Mpc about half the size of the expected cores. This is the resolution necessary to resolve a core the size of 300 pc. A 2 arcsec beam also matches the resolution of the Palomar IFU allowing for a good complementarity between observations made with the two instruments.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The dwarf galaxy dark matter survey described in this proposal will measure the radial distribution of dark matter (DM) in a sample of 13 DM dominated dwarf galaxies. The goal of the project is to determine the functional form of the DM distribution on scales of a hundred parsecs, and the degree to which the DM varies from galaxy to galaxy as a test of the Lambda CDM model on small scales. The scope of the project will permit for the first time the possibility of correlating the DM properites with other galaxy properties such as mass, gas density, star formation history, etc. We will measure the DM distribution by combining 2-D velocity fields of the galaxies in CO, which provides the least biased and coldest kinematic tracer at small radii together with Palomar Halpha integral field spectroscopy to extend the measurements to larger radii. Together with near-infrared imaging to secure the stellar mass distribution, we will remove the baryonic contribution to the observed rotation and model the kinematics. This data set will be the largest homogenious survey of the DM in the inner regions of galaxies undertaken to date.
